item.title: Obsidian Query Langauge plugin published
item.description: I’ve just published my first plugin for Obsidian! As a huge fan of the software the possibility of writing your own plugins to work with the data you create is just awesome! I’ve been using Obsidian for over 8 months now and one of the first things I created was the clipper. Since a few months Obsidian now allows users to write plugins in Typescript. While I’m not that versed in the Typescript/Javascript verse I did manage to write my first plugin!

item.title: Obsidian Clipper
item.description: This is an unofficial clipper for Obsidian that allows you to easily clip a selection to a note in Obsidian. More information can be found on Github or in this blogpost.

item.title: My daily journaling scripts for Obsidian
item.description: Since I’m quite a heavy user of Obsidian I’d like to share some of my scripts I’ve written for it. Please note that all of the scripts make use of Keyboard Meastro as a way to activate them and some of them use javascript automation within Mac OS X. So it’s Apple only for now. Within Obsidian I’m keeping a folder in which there are files that are used as a templates.

item.title: In search for a knowledge system
item.description: For years I’ve been looking for a system which would augment my own thinking with the help of the computer. One of the main promises of a digital life is things could more efficient. Or easily shareable and more resilient (Once you have backups..). For a meriad of reasons the switch should be obvious but for the most of us, that’s not what we experience. Why is that? I started of with just Word documents in folders.
